Comments_List: Understanding of what makes a movement radical right, the patterns of behavior that the radical right follow over time, how to think like a political scientist.

I learned a lot about french groups, political parties, and the ideologies of the far/extreme/radical right; how to categorize political ideologies; how the radical right plays out in various regions in Europe and in the United States.

I'm not sure why there is only a course called "Extreme and Radical Right Movements" offered and not "Extreme and Radical Left Movements" as well. Only illustrating one side of this extremism takes it entirely out of its relative context and demonizes just one group of people while intentionally overlooking its equally dangerous counterpart.
There was more lecturing than a standard seminar.
Moderating discussion better so we dont talk in circles

Strengths: very interesting readings; engaged professor; discussion-based class; a variety of teaching mechanisms
Weaknesses: learning about the radical right outside of Europe/the United States could be interesting and helpful
Yes, I'd recommend this course. The unique case studies and regional movements led to some very interesting discussions are radical right movements really that bad?
Yes. Excellent class. Very informative and engaging. One of the highlights of my week each week.

Absolutely. At Yale, there are not very many opportunities to study radical and extreme right movements and this course does an excellent job giving an overview of the academic literature and thinking surrounding them. It uses both this academic material and more contemporary focused media sources to provide students with an understanding of just how the radical right operates and how difficult it is to classify it.
I would recommend this course to any student intrigued by fringe politics
